shortdef: to move with your legs at a speed that is faster than walking —often used figuratively
to leave a place quickly by running —often + away —often + off
to run as part of a sport, for exercise, or in a race

stems: gives you a (good) run for your money
gives you a good run for your money
gives you a run for your money

dt: {bc}the general way in which something is moving or changing

dt.t: Investors are anxiously watching the {it}run{/it} of the stock market. [=are watching to see if the stock market is going up or down]
a bad case of {it}the runs{/it}

dt: {bc}an occurrence in which a large number of fish (such as salmon) swim up a river to return to the place where they were hatched and produce young

dt: Someone who {phrase}gives you a (good) run for your money{/phrase} in a game or contest makes it difficult for you to win by trying hard and playing or performing well.

dt.t: Though they lost, they {it}gave{/it} last year's champions {it}a run for their money{/it}.

dt: {bc}running away from someone in order to avoid being captured

dt.t: an escaped convict {it}on the run{/it}
He is {it}on the run{/it} from the cops.

dt: {bc}running away because you are about to be defeated

dt.t: The army had the enemy {it}on the run{/it}.

dt: {bc}while going somewhere or while doing something else

dt.t: We ate lunch {it}on the run{/it}.
He's always {it}on the run{/it}.

dt: {bc}the freedom to go anywhere or do anything you want in (a place)

dt.t: With his parents gone, he had {it}the run of{/it} the house.

def: {bc} to think about (something or someone) carefully especially in order to make a choice or decision
{bc} to think about (something that is important in understanding something or in making a decision or judgment)

dt: {bc}to think about (something or someone) carefully especially in order to make a choice or decision

dt.t: We are {it}considering{/it} you for the job.
She refused to {it}consider{/it} my request.
He seriously {it}considered{/it} changing careers.
The jury has {it}considered{/it} the evidence and reached a verdict.
The policy was well researched and well {it}considered{/it}.
Please {it}consider{/it} what I've said.
We never {phrase}considered the possibility{/phrase} that the plan could fail.
He paused a moment to {it}consider{/it} before responding.

dt: {bc}to think about (something that is important in understanding something or in making a decision or judgment)

dt.t: You have to {it}consider{/it} that he is only three years old.
When you {it}consider{/it} how long she worked there, it's surprising that she would leave so suddenly.
His achievements are very impressive when you {phrase}consider the fact{/phrase} that he never graduated from high school.

dt: {bc}to think about (a person or a person's feelings) before you do something in order to avoid making someone upset, angry, etc.

dt.t: You have to learn to {it}consider{/it} other people.
You never {it}consider{/it} my feelings.

dt: {bc}to think of or regard (someone or something) in a specified way

dt.t: I {it}consider{/it} the price (to be) too high.
We {it}consider{/it} careful work (to be) essential.
We {it}consider{/it} it an honor to have you here with us tonight.
a television program that is {it}considered{/it} one of the best comedies ever
He {it}considers{/it} himself to be a great writer.
{phrase}Consider yourself lucky/fortunate{/phrase} that you survived the accident. [=you are lucky to have survived the accident]

dt: {bc}to look at (someone or something) carefully and thoughtfully

dt.t: He stepped back to {it}consider{/it} the whole painting.

dt: used for saying that a statement is true when you think about all the good and bad parts or results of something

dt.t: {it}All things considered{/it}, we're pleased with how the project turned out.
It was a pretty good vacation, {it}all things considered{/it}.

dt: used to say that you will gladly do something that someone has asked you to do

dt: used to say that an activity, job, etc., has ended

dt.t: One more question and we're {it}done{/it}.
He'll travel many miles before he's {it}done{/it}. [={it}through{/it}]
My work is never {it}done{/it}. [={it}finished, completed{/it}]
I'm (almost) {it}done{/it} reading this book.
Turn out the light when you're {it}done{/it}.
Are you {it}done{/it} with the scissors?
When will you {phrase}be done with{/phrase} [={it}finish, complete{/it}] the project? = ({it}Brit{/it}) When will you {phrase}have done with{/phrase} the project?
Just call her and {phrase}be done with it{/phrase}. [={it}get it over with{/it}] = ({it}Brit{/it}) Just call her and {phrase}have done with it{/phrase}.
The cake is {it}done{/it}.
Check to see if the meat is {it}done{/it}.
Getting a divorce just wasn't {it}done{/it} at the time.

dt: {bc}in a very bad situation {bc}certain to fail, lose, be punished, etc.

dt.t: If she finds out we cheated, we're {it}done for{/it}. [={it}in trouble{/it}]
We'll never catch up now. We're {it}done for{/it}.
When we saw the explosion, we thought she was {it}done for{/it}.
After working in the garden all day, I was/felt completely {it}done in{/it}. [={it}exhausted{/it}]

stems: stopped me dead in my tracks

def: {bc} to not move, walk, etc., after doing so before
{bc} to cause (someone or something) to not move, walk, etc., after doing so before
{bc} to not do something that you have been doing before {bc} to not continue doing something

dt: {bc}to not move, walk, etc., after doing so before

dt.t: She was walking toward me, and then she suddenly {it}stopped{/it}.
The bus {it}stopped{/it} at the corner.
He {it}stopped{/it} to watch the sun set.
She had to {it}stop{/it} to catch her breath. = She had to {it}stop{/it} and catch her breath.
He {it}stopped{/it} to pick up a penny.
The car was going so fast that it couldn't {it}stop{/it} in time.
The traffic light turned red, so she had to {it}stop{/it}.
{it}Stop{/it}. [={it}halt{/it}] Who goes there?
I {phrase}stopped (dead) in my tracks{/phrase} [=stopped suddenly] when I saw the bear.

dt: {bc}to cause (someone or something) to not move, walk, etc., after doing so before

dt.t: {it}Stop{/it} that man! He stole my wallet.
They {it}stopped{/it} us at the border to check our passports.
She {it}stopped{/it} the car and turned back.
He was {it}stopped{/it} by the police for speeding.
The goalie {it}stopped{/it} [={it}blocked{/it}] the ball/shot.
The sight of the bear {phrase}stopped me (dead) in my tracks{/phrase}.

dt: {bc}to not do something that you have been doing before {bc}to not continue doing something

dt.t: He constantly teases her and never knows when to {it}stop{/it}.
We've been working all morning. It's time to {it}stop{/it} and take a break.
The boss said that he was unhappy with some of his employees, but he {phrase}stopped short of{/phrase} naming which ones. [=but he did not say which ones]
Did you ever {phrase}stop{/phrase} [={it}pause{/it}] {phrase}to think{/phrase} about the risk you took?
She never {phrase}stopped to consider{/phrase} how her decision might affect others.
Can you please {it}stop{/it} what you are doing to help me?
I {it}stop{/it} work at 5 o'clock.
The phone {it}stopped{/it} ringing.
{it}Stop{/it} arguing/talking/running.
She {it}stopped{/it} [={it}quit{/it}] smoking last year.
The patient suddenly {it}stopped{/it} breathing.
His heart {it}stopped{/it} beating.
{phrase}Stop it/that{/phrase} or I'll tell Mom.

dt: {bc}to make (someone or something) no longer do something {bc}to keep (someone or something) from continuing to do something

dt.t: I'm leaving and you can't {it}stop{/it} me.
{it}Stop{/it} me if you've heard this joke before.
It's too late. There's no {it}stopping{/it} them now. [=they can't be stopped now]
({it}Brit{/it}) I couldn't {it}stop{/it} him crying.
I couldn't {it}stop{/it} him {it}from{/it} crying.
He {it}stopped{/it} [={it}restrained{/it}] himself {it}from{/it} laughing out loud.
Nothing can {it}stop{/it} me {it}from{/it} leaving.
Environmentalists tried to {it}stop{/it} them {it}from{/it} cutting down the trees.
There is nothing to {it}stop{/it} you {it}from{/it} going.
We need to {it}stop{/it} the disease {it}from{/it} spreading.
The teacher {it}stopped{/it} the fight.
We need to {it}stop{/it} the violence in our city.
They tried to {it}stop{/it} the bleeding.
She {it}stopped{/it} the CD because it was skipping.
We {it}stopped{/it} [={it}paused{/it}] the movie to grab some snacks.

dt: {bc}to no longer happen or exist {bc}to end

dt.t: The music suddenly {it}stopped{/it}.
The path {it}stops{/it} about halfway up the mountain.
The rain had {it}stopped{/it} by the time we left. [=it was not raining anymore when we left]
The engine just {it}stopped{/it}.
His heart {it}stopped{/it}.

dt: {bc}to not travel during a journey for a short period of time in order to rest, eat, etc.

dt.t: We {it}stopped for{/it} lunch.
We need to {it}stop for{/it} gas. [=we need to get gas]
We {it}stopped for{/it} a night in Atlanta. [=we stayed in Atlanta for a night]

dt: {bc}to go to a place during a journey

dt.t: I'll {it}stop{/it} for a short visit.
The tour {it}stops{/it} in several cities.
I'm not {it}stopping{/it}. [={it}staying{/it}] I just wanted to drop this off.
He {it}stopped{/it} his ears with his fingers. [=he put his fingertips in his ears so that he couldn't hear]
She {it}stopped up{/it} the cracks with plaster.
The sink is {it}stopped up{/it} [={it}blocked{/it}] with food.

dt: {bc}to tell your bank not to pay a check

dt.t: I called to {it}stop{/it} payment on the check. = I called to {it}stop{/it} the check.
£200 will be {it}stopped{/it} [={it}withheld{/it}] {it}from{/it} your wages next week.

lbs: always followed by an adverb or preposition

dt.t: I am {it}stopping{/it} at home.

dt: used to say that someone will do anything to achieve a goal or purpose

dt.t: She will {it}stop at nothing{/it} to get what she wants.
Feel free to {it}stop by{/it} [={it}drop by, drop in{/it}] anytime.
I'll {it}stop by{/it} for a short visit.
You should {it}stop in{/it} [={it}stop by{/it}] for tea sometime.
I'm {it}stopping{/it} [={it}staying{/it}] {it}in{/it} tonight.

dt: {bc}to go or stay somewhere briefly while traveling to another place

dt.t: I'll {it}stop off{/it} (at the store) to pick up some milk.
She is {it}stopping off{/it} in Miami to visit a friend.
Could you {it}stop off{/it} at the house to water the plants?
He doesn't normally {it}stop out{/it} late.

dt: {bc}to go to or stay in a place while traveling to another place

dt.t: The plane {it}stops over{/it} in Chicago before going on to Seattle.
She {it}stopped over{/it} at a friend's house for a couple of days.
She {it}stopped up{/it} late last night.
